subject: Law
title: Separation of Powers Explained
description: A quick, practical guide to Separation of Powers Explained.

hook.text: What if the same person wrote laws, enforced them, and judged whether they were fair? That's tyranny.

buildup.text: The Constitution splits government into three branches: legislative, executive, and judicial.

discovery.text: Congress makes laws. The president enforces them. Courts interpret them. Each branch has its own lane.

twist.text: But the lanes overlap. The president can veto bills. Congress can override vetoes. Courts can void both.

climax.text: These 'checks and balances' prevent any single branch from dominating the others.

quiz.question: Why does the Constitution separate government into three branches?
options: To prevent any one branch from gaining too much power
